interest.translation[0].definitions[0].d: if you have an interest in something or someone, you want to know or learn more about them
interest.translation[0].definitions[0].e: I’d recommend this book to anyone who has an interest in jazz.
Ben has shown an interest in learning French.
My mother had never expressed any interest in the garden.
Babies soon begin to take an interest in the world around them.
John appeared to have no interest in girls.
I watched the first few episodes, but soon lost interest.
The last round of bidding aroused considerable interest.
Our survey reveals a disturbing lack of interest in teacher training.
I read your article with great interest.
My parents encouraged my interest in science.
interest.translation[0].definitions[1].d: an activity that you enjoy doing or a subject that you enjoy studying
interest.translation[0].definitions[1].e: His interests include walking and golf.
As a biologist, my main interest has been human genetics.
Her outside interests  (=interests that are not part of her work) were numerous.
interest.translation[0].definitions[2].d: a quality or feature of something that attracts your attention or makes you want to know more about it
interest.translation[0].definitions[2].e: A Persian rug will add colour and interest to your hallway.
It’s a book that will be of interest to a wide range of readers.
What you do in your private life is of no interest to me.
art galleries, museums and other places of interest
topics of general interest  (=that everyone wants to know about)
interest.translation[0].definitions[3].d: the extra money that you must pay back when you borrow money
interest.translation[0].definitions[3].e: How much are the monthly interest payments?
The interest on the loan is 16% per year.
interest.translation[0].definitions[4].d: money paid to you by a bank or financial institution when you keep money in an account there
interest.translation[0].definitions[4].e: an account that pays higher interest
The more you save, the more interest you’ll earn.
interest.translation[0].definitions[5].d: the things that bring advantages to someone or something
interest.translation[0].definitions[5].e: We’ve got to balance economic interests and environmental interests.
The regulations were introduced in order to safeguard the interests of local fishing communities.
The court decided that it was in the girl’s best interests to remain with her grandparents.
be in somebody’s (best) interest(s) (to do something)
He has your best interests at heart, you know.
interest.translation[0].definitions[6].d: if you have an interest in a particular company or industry, you own shares in it
interest.translation[0].definitions[6].e: The company is believed to be keen to sell its extensive brewing interests.
His business interests are spread throughout Europe.
In 1986 GM acquired a controlling interest in the sports car maker Lotus.
interest.translation[0].definitions[7].d: a group of people in the same business who share aims or ideas
interest.translation[0].definitions[7].e: Farming interests now dominate many of the National Park committees.
The majority of Brazil’s huge commercial interests support the measure.
the need to reduce the influence of special interests  (=groups who are concerned about particular subjects)
interest.translation[0].note_box[0].sect: have an interest in something
Steve has a keen interest in bird-watching.
show interest in something
He had shown great interest in her work.
express an interest in something
A number of well-known film directors have expressed interest in the script.
take an interest in something
Jacky first took an interest in golf when he was about six years old.
have no interest in something
Andy had no interest in politics.
lose interest in something
Tilda had lost interest in what was being said.
arouse/generate/attract interest
This extraordinary story has aroused interest in many quarters.
feign interest
Ted scanned the report, feigning interest.
interest grows
Interest in the project has steadily grown.
interest wanes
When his initial interest waned, the teacher paid more attention to him.
great interest
The government has shown great interest in the idea.
enormous/intense interest
This tournament has created enormous interest.
considerable/strong/keen interest
The results of their work will be of considerable interest.
special/particular interest
Natural history was a special interest of his.
a personal interest in something
He took a personal interest in the lives of his workers.
renewed interest
There has been a renewed interest in abstract painting in recent years.
a consuming interest
Roland had a consuming interest in cricket.
a long-term/abiding interest
She has had a long-term interest in antiques.
a lot of interest
There has been a lot of interest in the story.
a great deal of interest
The exhibition has generated a great deal of interest.
a lack of interest
The show was cancelled due to a lack of interest on the part of the public.
interest.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to make someone want to pay attention to something and find out more about it
interest.translation[1].definitions[0].e: Here’s an article which might interest you.
What interests me is all the history of these places.
It may interest you to know that a number of scholarships are available.
interest.translation[1].definitions[1].d: to try to persuade someone to buy, do, or eat something
interest.translation[1].definitions[1].n: Could I interest you in a drink/dessert etc? (=used as a polite way of offering someone a drink etc)
interest.translation[1].definitions[1].e: The salesman tried to interest me in the higher-priced model.
interest.translation[2].definitions[0].d: an amount paid by a borrower to a lender, for example to a bank by someone borrowing money for a loan or by a bank to a DEPOSITOR (=someone keeping money in an account there)
interest.translation[2].definitions[0].e: Any spare cash is best put in a savings account where it will earn interest.
US savings bonds will pay interest at 7.01% from May 1 through Oct. 31.
Some credit cards don’t charge interest on unpaid balances.
a period during which you only pay interest on the loan and make no capital repayments
interest.translation[2].definitions[1].d: shares that you own in a company, or a part of a company that a person or organization owns
interest.translation[2].definitions[1].e: Highlands Gold Ltd holds a 30% interest in the mine.
He acquired interests in a number of publishing companies.
interest.translation[2].definitions[2].d: a group of people with strong reasons for wanting something to happen because they will gain an advantage from it
interest.translation[2].definitions[2].e: He is determined to preventpowerful vested interests from blocking the reform.
interest.translation[2].definitions[3].d: the possession of rights, especially to land, property etc
interest.translation[2].definitions[3].e: The husband can release his interest in the legal estate to his wife.
